subject: Schumann, Robert, 1810-1856|Britten, Benjamin, 1913-1976|Saint-Saëns, Camille, 1835-1921|Telemann, Georg Philipp, 1681-1767|Regenstein Hall of Music (Evanston, Ill.)
table_of_contents: Track 1. How to breathe in the Romances -- How to make a recurring theme interesting each time it comes back -- Practicing underblowing or using minimal requirements to create a note without doing too much. Track 2. All work effort to creating sound should not be tight and contricting air flow -- Character of the piece and how to emulate Pan's character -- Clarity of notes need to come out even during passages with a lot of finger work -- Discussion about how to create a more passionate sound using breath pressure. Track 3. Discussion on musical ideas and techniques for excerpts -- Importance of musicality over technical ability. Track 4. Discussion on musical ideas and techniques for excerpts -- Importance of musicality over technical ability.

title: Oboe Master Class 1982-07-08

subject: Tchaikovsky, Peter Ilich, 1840-1893|Bizet, Georges, 1838-1875|Ravel, Maurice, 1875-1937|Schumann, Robert, 1810-1856
table_of_contents: Track 1. How to cushion the sound and play under the note -- Phrasing discussion -- Sound should be uninterrupted by the tongue. Track 2. Playing through the intervals fearlessly without playing too sharp on the way down -- Bending the pitch to find the ideal sound by experimenting with different embouchures.

title: Oboe Master Class 1983-07-20

collection: Ray Still Master Class Audio Archives
creator: Still, Ray
project: {'cycle': '2018', 'desc': 'Master class audio recordings of Ray Still. Part of a Master Class series. 9 cassettes and 58 reel to reel tapes', 'manager': 'Jen Young', 'name': 'Master Classes: Ray Still', 'proposer': 'Greg MacAyeal', 'task_number': 'P0044'}
subject: Schubert, Franz, 1797-1828|Brahms, Johannes, 1833-1897|Ravel, Maurice, 1875-1937|Rossini, Gioacchino, 1792-1868|Shostakovich, Dmitriĭ Dmitrievich, 1906-1975|Tchaikovsky, Peter Ilich, 1840-1893|Bach, Johann Sebastian, 1685-1750|Regenstein Hall of Music (Evanston, Ill.)
table_of_contents: Track 1. How to plan for breathing -- Techniques for working on lip and air pressure -- Articulation in fast passages that include slurs -- Planning breaths to work on phrasing and allowing phrasing to not be held down by breathing. Track 2. Taking your time with the tempo of "La Scala" -- Discussion of planning breaths to avoid disruption of the melody -- Good reeds should promote a round vowel sound rather than a restricted vowel sound -- The first F# of the Swan Lake excerpt must have an exciting, round tone that is in tune -- Importance of keeping the tone consistent throughout registers -- Exercises on how to get a clean articulation and sound at the beginning of notes.
terms_of_use: The audio recordings on this web site are provided for use by Northwestern University students, faculty, staff and guests. Further distribution and/or any commercial use of these recordings from this site is strictly prohibited.
title: Oboe Master Class 1983-07-14

collection: Ray Still Master Class Audio Archives
creator: Still, Ray
project: {'cycle': '2018', 'desc': 'Master class audio recordings of Ray Still. Part of a Master Class series. 9 cassettes and 58 reel to reel tapes', 'manager': 'Jen Young', 'name': 'Master Classes: Ray Still', 'proposer': 'Greg MacAyeal', 'task_number': 'P0044'}
subject: Tchaikovsky, Peter Ilich, 1840-1893|Brahms, Johannes, 1833-1897|Strauss, Richard, 1864-1949|Handel, George Frideric, 1685-1759|Lutkin Hall (Evanston, Ill.)
table_of_contents: Track 1. Pulse of excerpt in connection with orchestra/piano -- The solo must generate huge excitement toward the end -- Need for a meaty tone. Track 2. Have to have a concept of how you want to sound and use the equipment and practice to get there -- Emphasizes importance of ending phrases delicately -- Using "silly playing" to give students freedom and to encourage them to play out -- Not taking any extra time when breathing in orchestral solos -- People can usually hold their breath/play longer phrases than they think -- Discusses complexities of making it to the end of the Swan Lake solo. Track 3. Thinking operatically in the opening of Strauss -- Emphasizing importance of taking large breaths and ignoring the compulsion to take breaths more than needed. Track 4. Avoid distorting sound. Sometimes controlling sound just takes thinking about it and not specifically controlling your body -- Discussion about playing through the break of the oboe -- Performance anxiety and nervousness. How to prepare yourself for performance situations.
terms_of_use: The audio recordings on this web site are provided for use by Northwestern University students, faculty, staff and guests. Further distribution and/or any commercial use of these recordings from this site is strictly prohibited.
title: Oboe Master Class 1979-07-12

collection: Ray Still Master Class Audio Archives
creator: Still, Ray
project: {'cycle': '2018', 'desc': 'Master class audio recordings of Ray Still. Part of a Master Class series. 9 cassettes and 58 reel to reel tapes', 'manager': 'Jen Young', 'name': 'Master Classes: Ray Still', 'proposer': 'Greg MacAyeal', 'task_number': 'P0044'}
subject: Mozart, Wolfgang Amadeus, 1756-1791|Lutkin Hall (Evanston, Ill.)
table_of_contents: Track 1. Pickup figures must lead to next melodic section -- Not letting heavy quarter notes swell on each note, making sure they continue forward -- Longer notes must back away so melody can be heard -- Discusses vocal ideas of head-tone/chest-tone in regards to a clarinet melody. Track 2. Encourages sensitivity in vibrato and phrasing between oboe duet -- Works needs an active "tremendous" release -- Contrasts are important when large dynamic shifts happen consecutively -- Loud playing should never get nasty or out of a good sound. Track 3. Musicians must keep listening out of their music, not get behind the pulse -- Tune unison octaves to the lower note -- Piano dynamic is elevated when playing solo -- Tension works against getting air to be as strong as possible -- The art of middle playing is in the detaché -- Music is very passionate and must be played as such -- Players often feel that they are playing passionately when in fact they are playing bland, and listening to a recording of oneself shows this. Players must over exaggerate every feeling. Track 4. Tongue must not block resonance of the tone -- Oboe solos must be soaring and noble -- Piano dynamic playing requires the same amount of air as playing forte -- In slow movements, grace notes can be drawn out a bit more -- Crescendo and diminuendo should not impact the length of notes -- Solos must be played as if they are the most loved part of the music -- Bring out any non-chord tones or "blue notes" when they are present
terms_of_use: The audio recordings on this web site are provided for use by Northwestern University students, faculty, staff and guests. Further distribution and/or any commercial use of these recordings from this site is strictly prohibited.
title: Oboe Master Class 1979-07-19

subject: Mozart, Wolfgang Amadeus, 1756-1791|Hindemith, Paul, 1895-1963|Beethoven, Ludwig van, 1770-1827|Marcello, Alessandro, 1669-1747|Regenstein Hall of Music (Evanston, Ill.)
table_of_contents: Track 1. Importance of recording yourself playing and listen to how you relate to other instruments in volume and tone -- Focus on tone and volume and how to get a full sound -- Work on stress and release of notes -- Sound is changing constantly and how to properly listen to it -- Discussion of rhythmic accuracy -- Working on different reeds and the scale in this excerpt. Track 2. Practice like a pop singer in order to work on singing on the instrument -- Getting resonance on the instrument and finding the right emphasis on notes -- Explaining different techniques of how to improve tonguing.

title: Oboe Master Class 1982-07-09

collection: Ray Still Master Class Audio Archives
creator: Still, Ray
project: {'cycle': '2018', 'desc': 'Master class audio recordings of Ray Still. Part of a Master Class series. 9 cassettes and 58 reel to reel tapes', 'manager': 'Jen Young', 'name': 'Master Classes: Ray Still', 'proposer': 'Greg MacAyeal', 'task_number': 'P0044'}
subject: Mozart, Wolfgang Amadeus, 1756-1791|Marcello, Alessandro, 1669-1747|Hummel, Johann Nepomuk, 1778-1837|Telemann, Georg Philipp, 1681-1767|Bach, Johann Sebastian, 1685-1750|Regenstein Hall of Music (Evanston, Ill.)
table_of_contents: Track 1. Connecting between notes and how to correctly stress and destress notes -- Placing notes clearly during articulated passages to get a beautiful tone throughout -- Dramatic and comedic style that needs to be brought out -- Experimenting with articulating with a "gah" sound. Track 2. Importance of making an interesting sound even when playing with a straight sound -- Creating an even sound when playing through different intervals (avoiding head movement) -- Creating tone intensity without vibrato.

title: Oboe Master Class 1983-07-13

collection: Ray Still Master Class Audio Archives
creator: Still, Ray
file_sets: Track 1|Track 2|Track 3|Track 1|Track 2|Track 3|00000137v/1544bq60v.mods.xml|Tracks 1 and 2 technical metadata file|Track 3 technical metadata file|Tracks 1 and 2 asset front|Track 3 asset front
project: {'cycle': '2018', 'desc': 'Master class audio recordings of Ray Still. Part of a Master Class series. 9 cassettes and 58 reel to reel tapes', 'manager': 'Jen Young', 'name': 'Master Classes: Ray Still', 'proposer': 'Greg MacAyeal', 'task_number': 'P0044'}
subject: Mozart, Wolfgang Amadeus, 1756-1791|Lutkin Hall (Evanston, Ill.)
table_of_contents: Track 1. Descending scales must be played evenly -- Ritards should not be sudden or seem out of place -- 7th chords must be tuned appropriately and in the right balance -- Even when playing in the upper part of the instrument, one should try and make it as beautiful/in-tune as the rest of the instrument -- One must have mobility (in regards to pitch) while playing in order to do so artistically -- In pointed playing (dotted rhythms) there must be energy in each note and excitement in each note -- When the whole group takes a breath together it must be the same. If some instruments take less air and do not need as much air they still must match the breath of those who need more air. Track 2. Bass instruments are most important to be in tune -- Some solos must come to the front of the group without being so concerned with "steamrolling" over other members -- Some musical lines under slurs can be played with some articulation if that helps it sound more legato than if everything was slurred -- Even if something if forte it doesn't have to feel heavy and weighty -- The goal of the divertimenti should be to share the happiness of the music with the audience. Track 3. Allow room for stretching the music in a tasteful manner -- Discussion on stylistic choices of the piece -- Melody needs to dominate with more sound and musicality -- Avoid feeling too careful.

title: Oboe Master Class 1979-07-20

collection: Ray Still Master Class Audio Archives
creator: Still, Ray
project: {'cycle': '2018', 'desc': 'Master class audio recordings of Ray Still. Part of a Master Class series. 9 cassettes and 58 reel to reel tapes', 'manager': 'Jen Young', 'name': 'Master Classes: Ray Still', 'proposer': 'Greg MacAyeal', 'task_number': 'P0044'}
subject: Mozart, Wolfgang Amadeus, 1756-1791|Lutkin Hall (Evanston, Ill.)
table_of_contents: Track 1. Workshop of Mozart Serenade No. 11 -- Function of wind groups was to play for guests and events in courts, and octets would arrange the popular music of the day to play -- Finds balance and style of the music -- Group sound must remain strong even as a diminuendo happens. Track 2. Workshop of Mozart Serenade No. 11 -- Discusses playing passionately and lovingly -- Oboe players must match the dark color of the rest of the members of the octet -- Coaches the group on making appropriate color changes throughout sections. Track 3. Workshop on Mozart Serenade No. 12 -- Discusses differences in this piece as opposed to the other serenades, as well as the different characters between each section of No. 12 -- Discusses how to properly execute a forte-piano -- Says sforzandos are color changes, not splats. Track 4. Workshop on Mozart Serenade No. 12 -- Encourages players to relax and show the mood of the music in their playing -- Bassoon should not be pedantic or worried about every single note coming out, focus on the line.
terms_of_use: The audio recordings on this web site are provided for use by Northwestern University students, faculty, staff and guests. Further distribution and/or any commercial use of these recordings from this site is strictly prohibited.
title: Oboe Master Class 1979-07-16

collection: Ray Still Master Class Audio Archives
creator: Still, Ray

subject: Schumann, Robert, 1810-1856|Saint-Saëns, Camille, 1835-1921|Handel, George Frideric, 1685-1759|Mozart, Wolfgang Amadeus, 1756-1791|Pick-Staiger Concert Hall (Evanston, Ill.)
table_of_contents: Track 1. Playing around with the tempo to make it feel improvisational -- Improving pitch by practicing bending notes to get into pitch -- How to play a round note in an interesting way without sounding harsh and pinched. Track 2. Getting long notes to have a tender and projecting sound all while not allowing the pitch to wander -- Listening to your own tone and give it a human quality to it. Track 3. Playing a contrasting style with a scherzo versus dolce feeling -- Finding a light and bouncing nature in short notes similar to a bow bouncing off strings.

subject: Schumann, Robert, 1810-1856|Mozart, Wolfgang Amadeus, 1756-1791|Brahms, Johannes, 1833-1897|Regenstein Hall of Music (Evanston, Ill.)
table_of_contents: Track 1. Teaching on sforzando followed by a piano dynamic should always have a tone that is alive even after the climactic note -- Discussion about how air should move without using tension -- Discussion about breath pressure and how to control it. Track 2. Discussion about how to adjust proper amounts of reed in the mouth -- How to coax out a note by gripping the reed correctly -- Discussion of different reeds that allow for easier creation of sound.

subject: Beethoven, Ludwig van, 1770-1827
table_of_contents: Track 1. Playing into/under the note to avoid playing sharp -- Discussion of how to treat individual notes to be played in tune -- Working on detachment of notes. Track 2. Keeping air pressure high even during moments of less sound -- Discussion of rhythmic accuracy -- Avoiding stopping the sound with the throat. Track 3. Using the minimum muscular effort for maximum output -- Working on tuning longer notes.

title: Oboe Master Class 1983-07-18

collection: Ray Still Master Class Audio Archives
creator: Still, Ray
project: {'cycle': '2018', 'desc': 'Master class audio recordings of Ray Still. Part of a Master Class series. 9 cassettes and 58 reel to reel tapes', 'manager': 'Jen Young', 'name': 'Master Classes: Ray Still', 'proposer': 'Greg MacAyeal', 'task_number': 'P0044'}
subject: Bach, Johann Sebastian, 1685-1750|Handel, George Frideric, 1685-1759|Saint-Saëns, Camille, 1835-1921|Mozart, Wolfgang Amadeus, 1756-1791|Regenstein Hall of Music (Evanston, Ill.)
table_of_contents: Track 1. Following through on notes -- Embouchure fluctuation should always come from the jaw. Track 2. The tune should always be audible through the embelishments -- Let the front of the lips do the speaking of the sound. Track 3. Working on different fingerings for certain notes and trills. Track 4. Shouldn't have too much activity in notes. Practice separated notes with no activity (no vibrato). Track 5. Don't hold back the breath. Play with a kind of arrogance. Track 6. Staccatos need to be light and not hard articulation -- Being able to create a powerful sound that isn't harsh

title: Oboe Master Class 1981-06-23

subject: Mozart, Wolfgang Amadeus, 1756-1791|Regenstein Hall of Music (Evanston, Ill.)
table_of_contents: Track 1. Mozart Divertimento No. 3 in E flat Major. Students attending the Master Class featured in this track include: Paul Starks and Sally Bennet (oboe), Marianne Petersen and Steve Kaplan (English horn), Brain M. and Scott (clarinet), Daryl Caswell and Curt Ingram (horn), and Beth Heller and Randy Sulinka (bassoon). Track 2. Mozart Divertimento No. 2 in E flat Major. Students attending the Master Class featured in this track include: Sally Bennet and Steve Kaplan (oboe), Curt Ingram and Heidi Tepper (horn), and Randy Sulinka and Jeff Strong (bassoon).

title: Oboe Master Class 1979-07-20

collection: Ray Still Master Class Audio Archives
creator: Still, Ray
project: {'cycle': '2018', 'desc': 'Master class audio recordings of Ray Still. Part of a Master Class series. 9 cassettes and 58 reel to reel tapes', 'manager': 'Jen Young', 'name': 'Master Classes: Ray Still', 'proposer': 'Greg MacAyeal', 'task_number': 'P0044'}
subject: Strauss, Richard, 1864-1949|Brahms, Johannes, 1833-1897|Saint-Saëns, Camille, 1835-1921|Mozart, Wolfgang Amadeus, 1756-1791|Regenstein Hall of Music (Evanston, Ill.)
table_of_contents: Track 1. Any note you play should be capable of a diminuendo -- Practice stops and starts with notes. Track 2. Sometimes use harmonics to make a more stable note -- Take a large breath to give enough support through the end of the phrase -- "Small tone" or focused tone is necessary -- The reed should always be encouraged to be further inside mouth. Track 3. Start the air from the bottom of body -- Keep body stable in a "fight or flight" position. Track 4. Get into the bottom of notes. Track 5. Working on getting through the break with ease. Track 6. Keeping trills brilliant. Don't allow them to affect rhythm or tempo -- Working on articulation. Staccato needs to have clearer articulation rather than air attacks.

title: Oboe Master Class 1981-06-22

collection: Ray Still Master Class Audio Archives
creator: Still, Ray
project: {'cycle': '2018', 'desc': 'Master class audio recordings of Ray Still. Part of a Master Class series. 9 cassettes and 58 reel to reel tapes', 'manager': 'Jen Young', 'name': 'Master Classes: Ray Still', 'proposer': 'Greg MacAyeal', 'task_number': 'P0044'}
subject: Rossini, Gioacchino, 1792-1868|Debussy, Claude, 1862-1918|Shostakovich, Dmitriĭ Dmitrievich, 1906-1975|Regenstein Hall of Music (Evanston, Ill.)
table_of_contents: Track 1. Information about oboe and reed makers inside and outside of the United States -- Oboe Orchestra excerpts (student 1) -- Rossini, La scala di seta: How to play rhythmic accents -- Oboe Orchestra excerpts (student 2) -- Debussy, The Prelude to The Afternoon of A Faun: How to make a resonant ring in the sound -- Mozart Oboe excerpt. Track 2. How to play selective accents -- Mozart Divertimento, Oboe excerpt: how to keep sounds coherent throughout a music piece -- Shostakovich Symphony No.5, Oboe excerpt retaining the memory of sound. Track 3. Mozart Divertimento No. 8 -- Making bold and progressive sound without rushing -- How to play one rhythmic phrase together -- How to play continuous tones equally -- How to sit in a chair and use posture to produce better sound. Track 4. Discussion using about posture and seat position to produce better sound -- Mozart Divertimento No. 9 -- Tricky oboe and horn passages -- Maintaining same level of sounds -- Articulation with frontal type of consonants -- Expressive forte without pushing it too hard -- Making dolce sound without vibrato -- Vigorous and strong sound without rushing
terms_of_use: The audio recordings on this web site are provided for use by Northwestern University students, faculty, staff and guests. Further distribution and/or any commercial use of these recordings from this site is strictly prohibited.
title: Oboe Master Class 1980-07-24

collection: Ray Still Master Class Audio Archives
creator: Still, Ray
project: {'cycle': '2018', 'desc': 'Master class audio recordings of Ray Still. Part of a Master Class series. 9 cassettes and 58 reel to reel tapes', 'manager': 'Jen Young', 'name': 'Master Classes: Ray Still', 'proposer': 'Greg MacAyeal', 'task_number': 'P0044'}
subject: Brahms, Johannes, 1833-1897|Tchaikovsky, Peter Ilich, 1840-1893
table_of_contents: Track 1. Playing music should be articulate and shouldn't mumble, but shouldn't sound artificial as well -- Bending notes to work on placement of notes and control of notes -- Keeping the jaw open to keep air flowing and help get short notes out. Track 2. Getting a resonating sound on the oboe by singing to get rid of the constrictions of the oboe -- Playing piano doesn't mean playing tight and restricted -- Finding the right angle to put the reed to get the most resonant sound and opening up the possibility for more air. Track 3. Practicing bending notes in 3rds and 5ths to help get it in tune -- Exercises to work on stressing certain notes and de-stressing others -- Maneuvering the jaw in a flexible way to help with tuning. Track 4. Discussion of subtle diminuendos and how to keep the air moving -- Discussion of what to do physically in order to have an open sound. Track 5. How to approach the high C and play it delicately.

title: Oboe Master Class 1983-07-17

collection: Ray Still Master Class Audio Archives
creator: Still, Ray
file_sets: Track 1|Track 2|Track 3|Track 4|Track 1|Track 2|Track 3|Track 4|00000137v/2n49t3276.mods.xml|Tracks 1 and 2 technical metadata file|Tracks 3 and 4 technical metadata file|Tracks 1 and 2 asset front|Tracks 3 and 4 asset front
project: {'cycle': '2018', 'desc': 'Master class audio recordings of Ray Still. Part of a Master Class series. 9 cassettes and 58 reel to reel tapes', 'manager': 'Jen Young', 'name': 'Master Classes: Ray Still', 'proposer': 'Greg MacAyeal', 'task_number': 'P0044'}
subject: Mozart, Wolfgang Amadeus, 1756-1791|Lutkin Hall (Evanston, Ill.)
table_of_contents: Track 1. Wind playing should be molded after singing and not after other winds -- Discusses orchestral tuning techniques -- When playing operatic arrangements, the players not with the singer's melody must be out of the way -- Importance of oboe players emptying out bad air -- Ending cadenzas in a natural and elegant form. Track 2. Discusses playing Mozart Divertimenti -- Keeping tempo up through repeated staccato passages -- Appoggiatura must be played with emphasis on the non-chord note -- Mozart wrote serenades and divertimenti before advent of clarinets in Vienna -- Forte must have the same quality of sound as when playing piano. Track 3. When practicing scales nothing should stick out, all notes should be even -- Discusses blowing and "un-blowing" to find the threshold of the sound -- Encourages people to "sit tall" when they play, do not contract muscles that do not need to be contracted -- Matching phrasing of a melody even after a subito piano -- Importance of melodic lines following along with the solid 8th notes and entering at the correct time -- Discusses challenges of playing an overture arrangement for wind sextet. Track 4. Oboe must bring out skipping rhythm in the midst of a dense texture -- Not allowing forte-piano to swallow notes after the dynamic shift -- Performers must be aware of their operatic parts when playing a transcription.

title: Oboe Master Class 1979-07-17

project: {'cycle': '2018', 'desc': 'Master class audio recordings of Ray Still. Part of a Master Class series. 9 cassettes and 58 reel to reel tapes', 'manager': 'Jen Young', 'name': 'Master Classes: Ray Still', 'proposer': 'Greg MacAyeal', 'task_number': 'P0044'}
subject: Beethoven, Ludwig van, 1770-1827|Berlioz, Hector, 1803-1869|Rimsky-Korsakov, Nikolay, 1844-1908|Hindemith, Paul, 1895-1963|Schubert, Franz, 1797-1828
table_of_contents: Track 1. Discussion of separation of notes and what to do with the sound -- Discussion of purposing your reeds. Track 2. Navigating around the traps of the excerpt -- Tightening of important muscles vs unimportant muscles -- Controlling pitch in wide intervals. Track 3. Being flexible with vowels and changing tones with different vowels -- Playing detached notes doesn't mean stopping and starting the breath but rather blowing all at once. Track 4. Working on interval changes -- Discussion of how vibrato is produced and how it relates to accents.

title: Oboe Master Class 1983-07-19

collection: Ray Still Master Class Audio Archives
creator: Still, Ray
file_sets: Track 1|Track 2|Track 3|Track 4|Track 5|Track 6|Track 1|Track 2|Track 3|Track 4|Track 5|Track 6|00000137v/3197xn56h.mods.xml|Tracks 1 and 2 technical metadata file|Tracks 3 and 4 technical metadata file|Tracks 5 and 6 technical metadata file|Tracks 1 and 2 asset front|Tracks 3 and 4 asset front|Tracks 5 and 6 asset front
project: {'cycle': '2018', 'desc': 'Master class audio recordings of Ray Still. Part of a Master Class series. 9 cassettes and 58 reel to reel tapes', 'manager': 'Jen Young', 'name': 'Master Classes: Ray Still', 'proposer': 'Greg MacAyeal', 'task_number': 'P0044'}
subject: Handel, George Frideric, 1685-1759|Schumann, Robert, 1810-1856|Poulenc, Francis, 1899-1963|Mozart, Wolfgang Amadeus, 1756-1791|Regenstein Hall of Music (Evanston, Ill.)
table_of_contents: Track 1. Explanation of how to increase your dynamic range -- Keep muscles firm from belly button down and allow the upper muscles to be more relaxed. Track 2. Improving on diminuendo by keeping body planted and using proper breath support -- Practice by using breath only rather than including muscles. Track 3. Tempo for French music should be moving and not dragging -- Playing through rests and keeping it one continuous phrase -- Air has to be always blowing and always in large amounts to make both loud and soft dynamics. Track 4. Character change is absolutely necessary in this piece -- Jaw needs to hang so that it can find a position that doesn't make the sound sag. Track 5. Even when using a lot of air, the sound needs to be lean and not spread -- Discussion about clarity of articulation especially during fast articulated passages. Staccatos need to have more bite in order for the sound to come out clearly. Track 6. "Lifting tone out with legs" -- Practice fast breathing, like hyperventilating in order to teach your body to be used to irregular breathing.

title: Oboe Master Class 1981-06-25

collection: Ray Still Master Class Audio Archives
creator: Still, Ray
project: {'cycle': '2018', 'desc': 'Master class audio recordings of Ray Still. Part of a Master Class series. 9 cassettes and 58 reel to reel tapes', 'manager': 'Jen Young', 'name': 'Master Classes: Ray Still', 'proposer': 'Greg MacAyeal', 'task_number': 'P0044'}
subject: Ravel, Maurice, 1875-1937|Strauss, Richard, 1864-1949|Beethoven, Ludwig van, 1770-1827|Mozart, Wolfgang Amadeus, 1756-1791|Bach, Johann Sebastian, 1685-1750|Schumann, Robert, 1810-1856|Lutkin Hall (Evanston, Ill.)
table_of_contents: Track 1. In a fast triplet section, each note needs to be clear -- Breathe in a way that sets you up for good tone -- Detached notes in the upper register should be effortless -- Breath pressure should always be high to get the detached notes out -- Rhythmic accuracy in triplets. Track 2. Work on long diminuendos in order to play a quick diminuendo -- Avoid a stuck sound by working on how much reed goes in the mouth -- A natural but firm embouchure is necessary -- Allow your embouchure to imitate whistling. Track 3. Create space between teeth -- Breath pressure and embouchure pressure should be free to move and not locked -- Don't allow knuckles to get tight or tense -- Pressing too hard with hands may create pressure from mouth on reed -- Muscles need to be flexible even at forte. Track 4. Echo effect should also have change of color -- Active embouchure manipulates sound well.
terms_of_use: The audio recordings on this web site are provided for use by Northwestern University students, faculty, staff and guests. Further distribution and/or any commercial use of these recordings from this site is strictly prohibited.
title: Oboe Master Class 1980-07-23

collection: Ray Still Master Class Audio Archives
creator: Still, Ray
project: {'cycle': '2018', 'desc': 'Master class audio recordings of Ray Still. Part of a Master Class series. 9 cassettes and 58 reel to reel tapes', 'manager': 'Jen Young', 'name': 'Master Classes: Ray Still', 'proposer': 'Greg MacAyeal', 'task_number': 'P0044'}
subject: Brahms, Johannes, 1833-1897|Rossini, Gioacchino, 1792-1868|Beethoven, Ludwig van, 1770-1827|Saint-Saëns, Camille, 1835-1921|Ravel, Maurice, 1875-1937|Tchaikovsky, Peter Ilich, 1840-1893|Rimsky-Korsakov, Nikolay, 1844-1908|Lutkin Hall (Evanston, Ill.)
table_of_contents: Track 1. Improve tuning and tone by practicing wide vibrations -- Giving life and vibrato to a note can help with tuning. Track 2. Using core and stomach as a loose air bag to give notes volume and strength -- Use full air to get the most out of tone. Diminuendo should still use fast air -- Placing your oboe at a position of rest that is also easy to access when you get ready to play -- With dotted rhythmic figures, accenting notes slightly will give life to the line. Track 3. Avoid keeping the beat with your head -- Give long notes a "ring" to give it direction and energy -- An expressive piano is sometimes better than a forte -- Moving notes should still have a quality sound -- When you listen to yourself play, you must react and change while you play. Track 4. The audience can tell when you play a strained forte -- A stiff reed makes it hard for fast notes to speak -- Must have good equipment to facilitate good style and sound -- When you get tired, it is easy to start biting and straining for high notes -- There should still be some intensity in diminuendos.

title: Oboe Master Class 1980-07-22

collection: Ray Still Master Class Audio Archives
creator: Still, Ray
project: {'cycle': '2018', 'desc': 'Master class audio recordings of Ray Still. Part of a Master Class series. 9 cassettes and 58 reel to reel tapes', 'manager': 'Jen Young', 'name': 'Master Classes: Ray Still', 'proposer': 'Greg MacAyeal', 'task_number': 'P0044'}
subject: Mozart, Wolfgang Amadeus, 1756-1791|Lutkin Hall (Evanston, Ill.)
table_of_contents: Track 1. Forte can still be lyrical and beautiful -- Forte-piano is an expressive accent instead of a dynamic accent -- Repeated short figures should be bouncy and light, not heavy -- Imagine speaking a phrase instead of playing it. Track 2. Emphasis on two note figures is on first note -- Shows exercise of playing a note at forte and decreasing in volume with the same quality of sound -- Tells horn players about the correct interpretation of background figures -- "Sentimental slush" must be avoided in lyrical sections, keep the line clear and forward. Track 3. Encourages clarinet to be very expressive in "sigh" gesture -- Says Mozart's music is heavenly, encourages players to reach for "religious ecstasy" -- Expresses importance of always hearing the melody.

title: Oboe Master Class 1979-07-18

collection: Ray Still Master Class Audio Archives
creator: Still, Ray
project: {'cycle': '2018', 'desc': 'Master class audio recordings of Ray Still. Part of a Master Class series. 9 cassettes and 58 reel to reel tapes', 'manager': 'Jen Young', 'name': 'Master Classes: Ray Still', 'proposer': 'Greg MacAyeal', 'task_number': 'P0044'}
subject: Haydn, Joseph, 1732-1809|Beethoven, Ludwig van, 1770-1827|Brahms, Johannes, 1833-1897|Marcello, Alessandro, 1669-1747|Rossini, Gioacchino, 1792-1868|Lutkin Hall (Evanston, Ill.)
table_of_contents: Track 1. Discussion about flexibility of embouchure and air so that they can be moved at will -- Taking big breaths allow for better phrasing -- Separated notes should still have a full sound. Track 2. How to work on breath control and teach yourself to be comfortable with long phrases -- Discussion on dynamics and especially getting to subito piano -- How to bring different characters to a piece. Track 3. The need to simplify your air and prevent the sound from coming out franticly -- Bringing the oboe to you rather than bringing your body to the oboe -- Creating an even tone without bumps in sound -- Setting yourself up with a good breath in order to play with confidence. Track 4. Making short notes easy and calm -- Feeling serene in soloistic passages -- Long diminuendo must maintain same quality of sound throughout.

title: Oboe Master Class 1980-07-21

collection: Ray Still Master Class Audio Archives
creator: Still, Ray
project: {'cycle': '2018', 'desc': 'Master class audio recordings of Ray Still. Part of a Master Class series. 9 cassettes and 58 reel to reel tapes', 'manager': 'Jen Young', 'name': 'Master Classes: Ray Still', 'proposer': 'Greg MacAyeal', 'task_number': 'P0044'}
subject: Marcello, Alessandro, 1669-1747|Schumann, Robert, 1810-1856|Saint-Saëns, Camille, 1835-1921|Telemann, Georg Philipp, 1681-1767|Fiocco, Joseph Hector, 1703-1741
table_of_contents: Track 1. Sustaining notes in the correct way involves a correct embouchure that doesn't create too much tension -- Tremendous quantities of air needs to be moving even though the oboe cannot accept that much air -- Embouchure manipulation by pushing the reed in and out of the mouth is not helpful -- Practice yodeling on the oboe to work on finding the right sound -- Avoid bending into notes and approach them directly but have the support on the bottom of the note. Track 2. Play long tones that decrescendo without change in tone -- Finishing notes is an important skill to learn -- Understanding how much of the embouchure needs to move in order to be flexible with certain notes. Practice octaves slurred -- Sometimes an embouchure change isn't necessary but more air pressure can affect the tone and pitch positively -- A combination of embouchure and air pressure is necessary.

title: Oboe Master Class 1982-07-06

collection: Ray Still Master Class Audio Archives
creator: Still, Ray
project: {'cycle': '2018', 'desc': 'Master class audio recordings of Ray Still. Part of a Master Class series. 9 cassettes and 58 reel to reel tapes', 'manager': 'Jen Young', 'name': 'Master Classes: Ray Still', 'proposer': 'Greg MacAyeal', 'task_number': 'P0044'}
subject: Poulenc, Francis, 1899-1963|Bach, Johann Sebastian, 1685-1750|Strauss, Richard, 1864-1949|Mozart, Wolfgang Amadeus, 1756-1791|Regenstein Hall of Music (Evanston, Ill.)
table_of_contents: Track 1. Notes need to finish correctly. They need to finish with support and follow through -- Blow strongly through notes even with diminuendos. Track 2. Change of color is needed in order to avoid making the piece monotonous -- Allow for a darker color when piano has the theme -- Speak/talk into the reed to play detatched notes. Track 3. Large intervals need to be played in tune -- Come off tied notes early to get to the scale in time. Track 4. Chest should rise a little when blowing outwards -- Air must be consistent to keep the energy and life in the tone. Track 5. Mozart should be playful and joyful -- Playing quieter shouldn't result in a tighter sound. Track 6. When making a light sound, you can't have a tight embouchure -- The sound should have a grazziosso feeling with energy -- The slow movement shouldn't sound difficult to produce a flowing sound

title: Oboe Master Class 1981-06-24

collection: Ray Still Master Class Audio Archives
creator: Still, Ray
project: {'cycle': '2018', 'desc': 'Master class audio recordings of Ray Still. Part of a Master Class series. 9 cassettes and 58 reel to reel tapes', 'manager': 'Jen Young', 'name': 'Master Classes: Ray Still', 'proposer': 'Greg MacAyeal', 'task_number': 'P0044'}
subject: Strauss, Richard, 1864-1949|Brahms, Johannes, 1833-1897|Mozart, Wolfgang Amadeus, 1756-1791|Telemann, Georg Philipp, 1681-1767|Regenstein Hall of Music (Evanston, Ill.)
table_of_contents: Track 1. Don Juan Solo featuring Timothy Clinch -- How to play first sounds without delaying -- How do you play the line in the critical register of the oboe. Track 2. Brahms symphony No. 3, 3rd movement, oboe solo featuring Timothy Clinch -- How to play minor 3rd with piano -- How to play high-register sounds -- How to play secured high notes -- How to play from high register to low register (Donkey Exercise) -- How to practice detached notes. Track 3. Basic exercises -- Muscle control for posture (Mind over muscle) -- Fluctuating one vibration (Drunk WaWa exercise) -- Exercises in Mozart Oboe Quartet (28:00) -- Articulations with using tongue -- How to place scales in 3rd -- How to control your breath and volume to play long tones. Track 4. Six oboes each side for Telemann Fantasy Duet -- How to place high D and C# without making semi-tones -- How to manage short of breath (bottle-up feeling)

title: Oboe Master Class 1980-07-25

creator: Still, Ray

project: {'cycle': '2018', 'desc': 'Master class audio recordings of Ray Still. Part of a Master Class series. 9 cassettes and 58 reel to reel tapes', 'manager': 'Jen Young', 'name': 'Master Classes: Ray Still', 'proposer': 'Greg MacAyeal', 'task_number': 'P0044'}
subject: Strauss, Richard, 1864-1949|Vivaldi, Antonio, 1678-1741|Brahms, Johannes, 1833-1897|Beethoven, Ludwig van, 1770-1827|Lutkin Hall (Evanston, Ill.)
table_of_contents: Track 1. Using oboe concerti (Strauss, Mozart) to analyze and solve problems with oboe playing -- Phrasing studies in opening, pitch concerns -- Compares oboe playing to breaks in the voice -- Tuning pitches against a drone -- Discusses issues of specific instrument models -- Supporting over large intervals, landing in tune -- Encourages keeping baroque scores clean of marks (play as though you're improvising). Track 2. Discourages pinching sides of oboe reeds -- Breathing practices -- Reference Fritz Reiner recording -- Uses Brahms' second symphony for detached playing. Track 3. Practicing soft dynamics and keeping intensity -- Encourages practicing fundamental abilities/skills. Track 4. Playing orchestral excerpts imagining orchestra beneath you -- Emphasizes playing detached notes dolce

title: Oboe Master Class 1979-07-09

subject: Ravel, Maurice, 1875-1937|Regenstein Hall of Music (Evanston, Ill.)
table_of_contents: Track 1. Getting clear articulation on each note so it doesn't sound like mumbling -- The excerpt should almost feel arrogant and not mischevious -- Discussion about how to move tone quickly using breath and embouchure -- The quality of sound should always be consistent even throughout different notes. Track 2. Process of going through warm ups and getting ready before a performance -- How to get reeds ready before playing -- Discussion about problems with reeds and how to fix them -- Reed making discussion.

title: Oboe Master Class 1983-07-15

collection: Ray Still Master Class Audio Archives
creator: Still, Ray
project: {'cycle': '2018', 'desc': 'Master class audio recordings of Ray Still. Part of a Master Class series. 9 cassettes and 58 reel to reel tapes', 'manager': 'Jen Young', 'name': 'Master Classes: Ray Still', 'proposer': 'Greg MacAyeal', 'task_number': 'P0044'}
subject: Brahms, Johannes, 1833-1897|Schumann, Robert, 1810-1856|Beethoven, Ludwig van, 1770-1827|Lutkin Hall (Evanston, Ill.)
table_of_contents: Track 1. How to find your best sound and taper. Keeping focus to your sound. Track 2. Importance of finding a good reed and techniques to test your reeds -- What does an audition committee look for -- Accelerating air for high notes -- Playing lyrical forte. Track 3. Playing a rhythm intensely so it comes across clearly to the listener (Beethoven 6) -- Importance of listening to orchestral accompaniment while playing an orchestral solo -- Not allowing sound to dissipate as one diminuendos, especially in nuanced sections (Brahms 3) -- Difficulties of going from solo playing to accompanying other woodwinds in orchestral solos, not covering up other soloist (Brahms 2) -- Most difficult aspect of oboe playing is starting and stopping the tone -- Ensuring solos that are your first notes in the symphony still come out well and confidently -- If you can get solos to sound good very under tempo they will sound even better a faster speeds -- Encourages relaxing and not using muscles that are counterintuitive to oboe playing. Track 4. Building the tone up from the lowest partials, and playing solos slowly and lyrically to establish a solid tone -- Keeping the sound singing even in pianissimo dynamics (Brahms 1) -- Ray Still discusses various musical techniques and principles unrelated to certain repertoire -- Ray Still discusses players abilities to express themselves and reveal their "personality" in playing. Must have the technique to be able to express yourself, and a need to record yourself so that you can figure out what you need. Track 5. Ray Still discusses auditions and preparation -- Put yourself in the frame of mind of an audition before you are actually in one -- Ray Still discusses differences in playing in an orchestra and playing in a smaller ensemble.

title: Oboe Master Class 1979-07-13

creator: Still, Ray

subject: Bach, Johann Sebastian, 1685-1750|Britten, Benjamin, 1913-1976|Saint-Saëns, Camille, 1835-1921|Mozart, Wolfgang Amadeus, 1756-1791|Regenstein Hall of Music (Evanston, Ill.)
table_of_contents: Track 1. Stylistic choices for Bach -- How to play carefree under pressure -- 4 mechanisms to play Oboe: Breath, Embouchure, Tongue, Fingers -- Discussion about fingers and flexibility of the hand. Track 2. Working on finding important vs. unimportant notes -- Discussing stylistic choices -- How to create a line and direction with 8th notes -- Difference between blowing constantly and blowing (stopping) for each individual note.

title: Oboe Master Class 1983-07-12

collection: Ray Still Master Class Audio Archives
creator: Still, Ray
project: {'cycle': '2018', 'desc': 'Master class audio recordings of Ray Still. Part of a Master Class series. 9 cassettes and 58 reel to reel tapes', 'manager': 'Jen Young', 'name': 'Master Classes: Ray Still', 'proposer': 'Greg MacAyeal', 'task_number': 'P0044'}
subject: Brahms, Johannes, 1833-1897|Strauss, Richard, 1864-1949|Regenstein Hall of Music (Evanston, Ill.)
table_of_contents: Track 1. Use air to full extent, using all air until it completely runs out -- Don't be afraid to use more air than you think you might need. Blowing more air is better than trying to reserve air. Track 2. Discussion. Track 3. If air is used in excess, it gives a blaring sound which needs to be avoided -- Breaths can be taken frequently but must not disturb the musical line. Track 4. Psychological concept of always being ready to play. Never stopping the tension in your air. This allows players to be ready to play in any instant -- Keeping the breath active also helps keep the line in a phrase. Track 5. Idea of never taking 1 step at a time and instead taking 2-3 steps at a time to imitate the core muscles used when playing oboe -- Comparison with athletes that are always working on weak points, and always efficient with practice -- Glottal noise will sometimes come out because of the tension associated with playing but if it is too loud or intense, it is destructive. Track 6. Lecture.

title: Oboe Master Class 1981-06-26

collection: Ray Still Master Class Audio Archives
creator: Still, Ray
project: {'cycle': '2018', 'desc': 'Master class audio recordings of Ray Still. Part of a Master Class series. 9 cassettes and 58 reel to reel tapes', 'manager': 'Jen Young', 'name': 'Master Classes: Ray Still', 'proposer': 'Greg MacAyeal', 'task_number': 'P0044'}
subject: Mozart, Wolfgang Amadeus, 1756-1791|Mahler, Gustav, 1860-1911|Strauss, Richard, 1864-1949|Lutkin Hall (Evanston, Ill.)
table_of_contents: Track 1. Discusses the impacts of improper breathing in performances -- Keeping the integrity of phrasing/musicality up over long periods of time. Track 2. Uses Mahler's 4th symphony to work on implementing different types of vibrato and tone color. Track 3. Using highly pressurized bursts of air to improve sound and vibrato -- Not using the body to show expressiveness, but using the sound instead. Track 4. Stresses the importance of playing detaché and being competent -- Proper reed usage and picking the best reed -- Clarity of each note through articulation.

title: Oboe Master Class 1979-07-11

collection: Ray Still Master Class Audio Archives
creator: Still, Ray
project: {'cycle': '2018', 'desc': 'Master class audio recordings of Ray Still. Part of a Master Class series. 9 cassettes and 58 reel to reel tapes', 'manager': 'Jen Young', 'name': 'Master Classes: Ray Still', 'proposer': 'Greg MacAyeal', 'task_number': 'P0044'}
subject: Strauss, Richard, 1864-1949|Mozart, Wolfgang Amadeus, 1756-1791|Bellini, Vincenzo, 1801-1835|Lutkin Hall (Evanston, Ill.)
table_of_contents: Track 1. Playing cadenzas more slowly, working on fluidity -- Communication strategies with piano -- Must not use physical motion to "trick" audience in thinking they are playing expressively, not moving head around. Track 2. Discussing what "resonance" means in relation to harmonic proportions -- Ask for nuance in simple phrases -- Un-stressed notes must never be "puny" and lack tone. Track 3. Exercises on a smooth diminuendo without changes in sound/intonation -- Discusses how wrists/arms can have impact on embouchure and tone -- Shows exercise for playing a Bb with freedom and control -- Encourages mobility in the way we stand and being able to move (not related to the rhythm of the music). Track 4. Discussion about clear articulation. Practicing using "Morse code" -- How to use air and muscle groups to efficiently create sound. "Vomiting into the oboe." Track 5. Discussion of finishing phrases and finishing notes without a drop in tone -- How to do less work by using your body more efficiently. Track 6. Performance of Strauss 2nd Movement by Ray Still.

title: Oboe Master Class 1979-07-10
